awd_titl_txt: LEAPS-MPS: Advancing Approximation of Heterogeneous Multi-Objective Set Covering Problems with Modeling and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). The goal of this project is to approximate large-scale optimization solutions associated with decision-making in conservation planning and emergency medical service management, through theoretically-sound and efficient models and algorithms.  The broad applicability of the project is in advancing optimization tools to integrate voluminous spatial data to effectively allocate resources and analyze information such as species distribution, population parameters, the spatial configuration of reserves, land costs, and environmental dynamics. In establishing a strategy it is necessary to estimate the quality of the approximation beforehand to efficiently use the available resources and successfully address future adverse conditions. To better understand the limits of approximating the solution of an optimization question, a significant component of the developed algorithms is the predetermined quality measure, where the optimal solution set is always guaranteed to be within a predetermined error.  The project integrates educational and outreach activities with the goal of broadening participation of underrepresented groups in STEM fields. 


This project focuses on multiobjective optimization (MO), and specifically on generalized set covering questions (MOSCPs) and approximation algorithms with predetermined quality measures, to enable the solutions of decision-making optimization in conservation planning and emergency medical service management. Among MO techniques, the generalized MOSCP emerges as a computationally intensive challenging method whose theory and methodology remain underdeveloped, the technical theme of this project is the theoretical and computations investigation of its structural properties using mathematical programming. MO questions typically do not have optimal solutions in the totally ordered sense of single objective optimization; instead, they have optimal solutions in a partially ordered sense appropriate in the presence of multiple conflicting objectives, and the success of their application depends on the ability to compute the elements of the solution set, the so-called Pareto set. A large portion of this project is devoted to investigating computationally efficient alternative methods to approximate the Pareto set in mixed integer multiobjective optimization questions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to advance the understanding, solution methods, and practical applications of Heterogeneous Multi-Objective Set Covering Problems (MOSCP), with a particular emphasis on approximation techniques. As a subclass of multiobjective combinatorial optimization  problems, MOSCP presents significant computational challenges due to its combinatorial structure and the inherent complexity of balancing multiple conflicting objectives.

The project made significant strides in developing systematic and structured mathematical models, including generalized MOSCP formulations that integrate the problem as a subcomponent of broader optimization frameworks. Approximation methods were advanced using weighted-sum and weighted max-ordering scalarization techniques, incorporating four distinct weight computation methods to achieve precise solutions. Theoretical properties were established to evaluate approximation quality, and a novel cost-effectiveness vector was introduced and rigorously validated.

The project also tackled uncertainty in set covering problems by conducting a comprehensive review of modeling and solution approaches. This review explored the challenges posed by uncertain parameters and proposed future research directions to enhance decision-making under uncertainty. Building on this foundation, a generalized framework was introduced to address multiobjective combinatorial optimization problems with uncertain objective function coefficients. This framework constructed a statistically meaningful reference-nondominated set, defined a sensitivity region based on confidence levels, and ranked decisions using an auxiliary optimization model and index map.

Further advancements were made in addressing feasibility uncertainties in multiobjective integer linear programming problems. The project developed an Uncertain Decision Space  using robust optimization and chance constraint techniques, enabling solutions to be evaluated against risk levels defined by Poisson and Binomial distributions. This framework ensured compliance with budget constraints while supporting informed decision-making. Results were demonstrated through illustrative examples, including MOSCP applications.

For environmental conservation SCP applications, the project developed a comprehensive suite of generalized set covering models to address critical objectives of compactness and connectivity. A heuristic algorithm was introduced to create corridors and design connected reserve systems. These efforts led to the development of the optimization tool MODERN (Methods of Optimization for Designing Ecological Reserves in Nature), which has been made publicly available on GitHub. A novel compactness metric, integrating considerations of size and shape, was proposed and compared to traditional metrics like boundary length and pairwise distance. The results demonstrated the superiority of multiobjective optimization in generating Pareto-optimal reserve configurations for conservation planning.

For the location science SCP application, a generalized set covering model and a quadratic programming-based approximation algorithm were developed to address the smallest enclosing circle problem. This work optimized healthcare communication hubs by minimizing facility setup costs and ensuring efficient communication. The model was validated through hypothetical and real-world scenarios in Dougherty County, Georgia, highlighting novel approaches for future hub construction.

To date, the project has resulted in two peer-reviewed publications, one M.S. thesis, multiple research talks and four manuscripts currently under review. It has significantly advanced the theory and application of multiobjective optimization, particularly in MOSCP, with broad applications in conservation, public health, and beyond. Furthermore, the project has achieved meaningful broader impacts by fostering STEM education through research opportunities for a diverse group of students, including undergraduates, MS students, and Ph.D. students. It has also promoted community engagement and learning in optimization and mathematical modeling through outreach efforts.
